visits.text: You cross the border into Botswana at Ngoma Bridge. Border formalities take 30 minutes to an hour.
Kasane is the gateway to Chobe National Park, famous for having the largest elephant concentration in Africa.
The town is small but lively, with tour operators, restaurants and lodges along the Chobe River.
Full day in Chobe National Park, one of Botswana's wildlife crown jewels.
The park is home to an estimated 120,000 elephants, the largest population in the world.
Besides elephants, you can see lions, leopards, buffalo, giraffes and hundreds of bird species.

activities.text: Border crossing Namibia-Botswana at Ngoma Bridge.
Afternoon boat safari on the Chobe River to observe elephants, hippos and crocodiles.
Camping at Chobe Safari Lodge or Thebe River Safaris campsite.
Morning game drive in Chobe National Park.
Afternoon boat safari on Chobe River, complementing morning land safari.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: Enjoy your last morning for a safari then head towards Maun.
You end your journey on the banks of the Thamalakane River.
There you go, your fantastic journey comes to an end. You head to the depot to drop off your vehicle then you're taken to the airport to board your return flight.

activities.text: Final morning safari before heading to Maun.
Vehicle return in Maun.
Transfer to Maun airport for your return flight.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: Long drive day from Savuti to Moremi Game Reserve via Khwai.
You gradually enter the Okavango Delta ecosystem, with more water and lush vegetation.
Moremi is a mosaic of lagoons, channels, islands and forests in the heart of the delta.
You leave the Savuti area to reach Moremi Reserve, crossing the route connecting northern Chobe to the delta's heart.
The drive is long and sometimes demanding depending on track conditions.
This region's interest lies in its geographic position: you're at the delta ecosystem's heart, with direct access to tracks where wildlife is particularly present.
You're at the heart of the Okavango Delta ecosystem, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Moremi Reserve protects a mosaic of lagoons, forests and plains where the Big Five live.

activities.text: Drive to Moremi via Khwai, wildlife viewing en route.
Enter Moremi Game Reserve at North Gate, pay park fees.
Afternoon game drive in Moremi towards your campsite.
Safari on Moremi tracks, in the heart of Okavango Delta.
Camping at Third Bridge or Xakanaxa inside Moremi.
Morning safari on Moremi tracks.
Explore different delta ecosystems: lagoons, mopane forests, floodplains.
Possible mokoro (traditional canoe) excursion from certain camps.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: You head towards Savuti, a remote region in the heart of Chobe National Park.
The drive is long and sometimes challenging depending on track conditions. Plan 5-6 hours of driving.
Savuti is known for its large predator populations, particularly lions and hyenas that hunt the migrating zebras.
Full day exploring the Savuti area, one of the best wildlife viewing regions in Botswana.
The marsh, though often dry, attracts large concentrations of wildlife, especially during zebra migration season.
Rock paintings at Gubatsa Hills testify to ancient human presence in this now remote area.
Another day in Savuti to maximize your chances of exceptional wildlife sightings.
The area is vast and each drive offers different encounters depending on animal movements.
Patience is often rewarded here with sightings of rare species or dramatic predator-prey interactions.
Final morning in Savuti before beginning your journey towards the Okavango Delta.
Take advantage of these last hours for a final game drive in this exceptional area.

activities.text: Long drive on sandy tracks to reach Savuti.
Late afternoon game drive around Savuti Marsh.
Camping at Savuti public campsites, basic facilities in wild setting.
Morning game drive in Savuti, prime predator watching area.
Visit Gubatsa Hills to see ancient rock paintings, short hike from parking area.
Afternoon game drive exploring different areas around Savuti Marsh.
Full day of game drives in Savuti region, exploring various tracks and waterholes.
Focus on finding specific species: wild dogs, cheetahs, or the famous Savuti lion prides.
Early morning game drive, last chance in Savuti.
Pack up camp after breakfast and prepare for the long drive to Moremi.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: The wild horses of Garub graze near a water point 20 km from Aus. These feral horses, descendants of German cavalry mounts from World War I, have adapted to the desert for over a century.

Aus itself is barely more than a handful of houses and a gas station. But this hamlet marks a strategic crossroads: south towards Lüderitz, west towards Sossusvlei, north towards the Naukluft Mountains.

activities.text: Long drive through desert plains. The C13 and C27 cross lunar landscapes where only oryx and ostriches survive. Long straight stretches, mirages on the horizon. Refuel in Aus.
Desert camping at Aus. Klein-Aus Vista or nearby campgrounds offer total immersion in the silence of the Namib. Night falls, stars blanket the sky. Only the calls of jackals break the desert silence.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure

visits.text: You leave the coast to head inland towards Brandberg, Namibia's highest massif (2,573m).
The landscape gradually changes from coastal plains to rocky desert and granite mountains.
The Brandberg massif is famous for its ancient rock art, particularly the White Lady painting dating back over 2,000 years.

activities.text: Hike to see the White Lady rock painting with a local guide (mandatory).
Camping near Brandberg, basic campsites with stunning views of the massif.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: You enter the Caprivi Strip (now Zambezi Region), a narrow corridor of Namibian territory between four countries.
This region is totally different from the rest of Namibia, lush and watered by several rivers: Okavango, Kwando, Chobe and Zambezi.
The landscape is a mix of forests, marshes and river plains, with rich birdlife and aquatic wildlife.

activities.text: Game drive in Bwabwata National Park, crossing between Rundu and Katima Mulilo.
Optional boat trip on the Okavango or Kwando rivers to observe hippos and crocodiles.
Camping in the Caprivi Strip, several options along the rivers.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: Spectacular route to Epupa Falls landscapes Kaokoland isolated mountains.
Kunene River Angola border permanent waters arid region.
Epupa Falls 37-meter waterfalls baobabs makalani palms.
Series of waterfalls green landscape desert contrast.
Authentic Himba villages encounter with pastoral ethnic group and millennial traditions.
Circular hut dwellings okuruwo constructed with earth and dung.
Ceremonies and rituals with otjize red ochre paste and symbolic butter.
Lifestyle of goat and cattle herding with semi-nomadism.

activities.text: Hiking Epupa Falls waterfalls natural pools refreshing swimming.
Crocodile watching Kunene river basin aquatic wildlife.
Walk through palm groves giant baobabs unique tropical landscape Namibia.
Visit Himba village traditions red ochre hairstyles omuzumba paste.
Observation of semi-nomadic lifestyle goat and cattle herding.
Sunset over Kunene River with panoramic views of Angola mountains.
Grilled tiger fish from Kunene River.
Windhoek Lager beer and South African Sauvignon wine.
Respectful visit to Himba villages with cultural exchanges about traditions and hairstyles.
Observation of otjize ochre paste making for sun protection and beauty symbolism.
Meeting Himba women with shell and metal jewelry and shepherd children.
Learning breeding techniques for survival in isolated arid regions.
Hiking through Kunene gorges with wild landscapes, baobabs and river.
Tasting Himba curdled milk omaere traditional drink.
Grilled goat meat pastoral cuisine.
Local beer South African red wine.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure
Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure

visits.text: You cross Etosha from west to east, stopping at multiple waterholes for game viewing.
The pan stretches endlessly, a vast white expanse that shimmers under the sun, occasionally animated by herds crossing.
Halali and Namutoni waterholes offer excellent wildlife watching opportunities throughout the day.

activities.text: Full day of game drives in Etosha, visiting various waterholes.
Visit to Namutoni Fort, historic German colonial fort now a camp with viewing tower.
Camping at Namutoni or Halali NWR camps.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: Long drive to Etosha National Park, one of Africa's greatest wildlife reserves.
You enter via Anderson Gate on the southern side and head to your campsite inside the park.
Your first game drive in Etosha begins. The park is famous for its salt pan and abundant wildlife concentrated around waterholes.

activities.text: Evening game drive towards Okaukuejo waterhole, one of Etosha's most famous spots.
Camping at Okaukuejo NWR camp or nearby lodges.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

activities.text: Dawn safari from Okaukuejo. Leave at sunrise when the park gate opens. Animals are most active in morning cool. Drive slowly, scan waterholes, observe behaviors. Lions return from night hunting, elephants quench their thirst, giraffes browse acacias.

Route to Halali camp. The 70 km crossing Etosha is pure safari. Stop at each waterhole: Ozonjuitji m'Bari, Okondeka, Salvadora. Each has its regulars. Elephants here, zebras there, sometimes a rhino in the distance.

Arrival and installation at Halali. This camp nestled in mopane forest offers a shaded, wilder atmosphere than Okaukuejo. Its waterhole, visible from the restaurant terrace, attracts leopards at dusk – rare privilege.

Afternoon safari loop. From Halali, explore southern tracks towards the pan. The white expanse of Etosha Pan appears in the distance – dry most of the year, transformed into a shallow lake after rains. Watch for lions in the shade of acacias.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure

visits.text: Route to Kamanjab, Kunene region, dense savanna bush.
Agricultural town, cattle farming, center of Herero community.
Transition landscapes from Kaokoland to central Namibian highlands.

activities.text: Crossing savanna bush landscapes, wildlife observation, birds of prey.
Stop at Herero villages, meeting communities, traditions, Victorian dresses.
Visit farm livestock discovery Namibian agriculture cattle.
Observation sunset savanna warm colors African ambiance.
Tasting biltong dried meat Namibian specialty kudu oryx.
Braai sausages boerewors grilled meats.
Hansa Pilsener beer South African Merlot wine.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure

visits.text: Route to Damaraland semi-desert landscapes Brandberg mountains.
Khorixas capital of Damaraland commercial center of the region.
Petrified Forest petrified forest 260 million years fossilized trunks.
Prehistoric gymnosperm trees silica petrification.

activities.text: Exploration of Petrified Forest petrified tree trunks 30 meters lunar landscape.
Observation of geological formations prehistoric fossils paleontology.
Meeting with Damara guide explanations geology history.
Tasting of potjiekos stew vegetables meat iron pot.
Mahangu porridge millet paste traditional Damara.
Windhoek Lager beer South African wine Chenin Blanc.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure

visits.text: Mariental marks the gateway to the red dunes of the Kalahari. This small farming town offers one last chance to refuel and stock up before diving into the desert landscapes.

activities.text: Route to the Kalahari. The C20 plunges south through increasingly arid landscapes. Red sand replaces gray gravel, thorn acacias thin out. The true Kalahari begins here.

First sunset on the red dunes. The Kalahari Lodge campsites nestle at the foot of orange dunes dotted with acacias. Climb a dune before dinner: the setting sun sets the sand ablaze in shades of copper and gold.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure

visits.text: Fort Namutoni stands like a white citadel at Etosha's eastern edge. This German colonial fort built in 1903 now houses a museum on Etosha history. Climb the tower for views over pan and surrounding plains.

activities.text: Dawn safari from Halali. Morning light is magical on Etosha. Scan waterholes for predators finishing night hunting. Sometimes cheetahs rest on termite mounds, silhouette against rising sun.

Route to Namutoni. This third camp marks Etosha's eastern end. The landscape changes: grasslands become denser, vegetation greener. Fisher's Pan and Klein Namutoni waterholes are particularly productive for bird watching.

Installation at Namutoni. This elegant fort-camp offers colonial charm atmosphere. Its waterhole just outside the walls attracts elephants, giraffes, zebras. Pool and lawn under palm trees complete the colonial Africa setting.

Afternoon safari towards the pan. Take the eastern track to viewpoints over Etosha Pan's immense white expanse. In dry season, mirages shimmer on the horizon. After rains, thousands of flamingos gather – surreal pink spectacle.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure

visits.text: Morning guided tour at Twyfelfontein. Your San guide deciphers the engravings: hunting scenes, animal tracks, shamanic visions. Each rock tells a story from a time when humans and animals shared this now-arid land.

activities.text: Long route to Etosha. The C43 then C38 cross increasingly green landscapes. Mopane trees appear, signs of approaching water sources. Entrance through Anderson Gate on the western side. Drive across the park to Okaukuejo camp.

Arrival at Okaukuejo camp. This historic camp is famous for its waterhole visible 24/7 from behind a low wall. Check in, set up tent, then first safari loop before sunset. Elephants, zebras, springbok gather near waterholes as evening approaches.

Night vigil at Okaukuejo waterhole. After dinner, settle behind the wall overlooking the floodlit waterhole. Elephants arrive in silence, rhinos grunt as they drink, sometimes lions appear. Staying up until midnight is worth it – the spectacle is hypnotic.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure

visits.text: Opuwo capital Kaokoland border town himba herero zemba.
Local market himba crafts jewelry leather red ochre.
Mountainous isolated region preserved ancestral traditions.
Return to Opuwo through mountainous Kaokoland landscapes and isolated villages.
Crossing plateaus observing wildlife springboks oryx kudus.
Panoramic stops wild mountains raw beauty.

activities.text: Visit Opuwo market encounter himbas herero traditional costumes jewelry.
Exploration border town unique atmosphere cultural blend.
Shopping local crafts red ochre bracelets wood sculptures.
Preparation visit himba villages respect cultural protocols.
Tasting oshifima goat meat pastoral cuisine.
Castle Lager beer Cape red wine.
Scenic route through Kaokoland mountains observing scattered traditional villages.
Photography stops grandiose landscapes golden afternoon light.
Meeting with Herero herders, cattle herds, pastoral traditions.
Exploration of Opuwo surroundings, rocky hills, 360-degree panoramas.
Tasting of ombidi, mopane caterpillars, traditional grilled proteins.
Grilled beef, Namibian braai.
Tafel Lager beer, South African Pinotage wine.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure
Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure

visits.text: Outjo gateway to Etosha small town stopover towards national park.
German colonial architecture Lutheran church historic center.
Agricultural region highlands temperate climate agriculture livestock.

activities.text: Exploration Outjo town center colonial architecture artisan shops.
Visit local markets Damara crafts wood stone sculptures.
Walk through gardens parks greenery peaceful atmosphere small town.
Preparation safari Etosha provisions equipment binoculars guides.
Tasting kudu pie meat pie game meat specialty Outjo.
Game meat platter assortment wild meats.
Windhoek Lager beer South African wine Chenin Blanc.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure

visits.text: Palmwag Lodge private reserve 400000 hectares wildlife black rhinos.
Conservation concession desert elephants giraffes adapted lions.
Spring palm trees oasis greenery arid region Damaraland.

activities.text: Safari rhino tracking black rhino search endangered species protection.
Desert elephant observation herds adaptation unique behavior.
Giraffe encounter desert adaptation specific morphology.
Nature hike bush savanna expert guide fauna flora.
Game drive sunset observation lions hyenas cheetahs.
Braai grilled meats oryx kudu boerewors.
Hansa Pilsener beer red Stellenbosch wine.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure

visits.text: You leave Etosha heading northeast towards Rundu, a long drive of about 6 hours through northern Namibia.
The landscape changes from dry savannah to more verdant regions as you approach the Okavango River.
Rundu is a river town on the border with Angola, with a more tropical feel than southern Namibia.

activities.text: Transit day, plan rest stops and fuel at Tsumeb or Grootfontein.
Relax by the Okavango River in Rundu, sunset views over the water.
Camping at riverside lodges near Rundu.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: Route to Kaokoland remote wild region northwest Namibia.
Sesfontein German colonial fort 1896 date palm oasis.
Permanent water source desert historical importance caravans.
Mountainous landscapes Kaokoland raw beauty isolation.

activities.text: Exploration of Sesfontein fort German colonial architecture military history.
Walk through palm grove oasis contrast desert greenery freshness.
Meeting with Herero community traditions pastoral culture.
Bird watching water source raptors waders migratory birds.
Tasting oshifima corn paste traditional Herero dish.
Kapana grilled meat street spices.
Windhoek Draught beer South African white wine.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure

visits.text: Sesriem Canyon cuts a narrow gorge 30 meters deep into sedimentary rock. Walk through this natural corridor carved by the Tsauchab River over millennia. The name 'Sesriem' (six thongs) comes from the rope length needed to draw water from the bottom.

Sossusvlei: the iconic white clay pan surrounded by dunes over 300 meters high. Dune 45, the most famous, offers a relatively accessible climb (30-45 min ascent). From the summit, the view sweeps over an ocean of orange dunes to the horizon.

Deadvlei: the dead vlei. An ancient clay pan where skeletal camelthorn trees have stood for 900 years, killed by drought. The contrast between white clay, black trees, orange dunes, and blue sky creates a surreal landscape that photographers dream of.
After breakfast, you leave Windhoek heading southwest. The drive to Sesriem takes about five to six hours, mostly on well-maintained dirt roads.
It crosses savannah landscapes, open plains and initial reliefs, with few villages but some possible stops for a break or fuel.
In early or mid-afternoon, you arrive in the Sesriem region, gateway to Namib-Naukluft National Park.
You wake up very early, around 5:30 AM, to enter the park at sunrise and climb the dunes with cooler temperatures.
The drive to Sossusvlei takes about an hour on a tarred road, then the last 5 km on deep sand (4x4 shuttle or walking).
The dunes of Sossusvlei, some of the highest in the world, offer an extraordinary spectacle at sunrise. The light plays on the orange sands and the dead trees of Deadvlei.
On the way back, stop at Sesriem Canyon, a small rocky gorge carved by the Tsauchab River.

activities.text: Route to Sesriem via the C19. The landscape transforms: flat plains give way to undulating dunes. The red sand becomes more intense. Arrival at Sesriem campground for check-in and setup.
Afternoon visit to Sesriem Canyon. After the heat of the road, this shaded gorge offers welcome respite. Explore the narrow passages, photograph the layers of rock, spot rock hyraxes on the walls.
Preparation for Sossusvlei dawn departure. Park gates open at sunrise (around 6am). Prepare breakfast, fill water bottles, charge cameras. Go to bed early: tomorrow's alarm rings at 5am.

Dawn departure for Sossusvlei. Leave camp at 5h30 am to be at the gate at opening. The 65 km of tar road passes Dune 45 (first stop), then reaches the 2x4 parking. Shuttle or 4x4 in deep sand for the last 5 km to Sossusvlei/Deadvlei.
Return to camp at midday. The sun beats down, temperatures soar. Back to Sesriem for lunch in shade and siesta. The campsite pool becomes precious refuge during hottest hours.
Optional afternoon: Elim Dune or Sesriem Canyon. Elim Dune (5 km from camp) offers a sunset climb with 360° views. Alternative: return to Sesriem Canyon in soft afternoon light for photography.
The road is long, plan regular breaks and fuel up at Rehoboth or Solitaire.
Enjoy the end of the day to settle in and rest before tomorrow's big day.
Camping at Sesriem NWR or in a private campsite nearby.
Climb Dune 45 or Big Daddy (300m high) for panoramic views over the desert.
Walk among the dead trees of Deadvlei, surreal landscape with 900-year-old acacia skeletons.
Visit Sesriem Canyon, small but impressive gorge 30m deep.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure
Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: Spitzkoppe rises like a granite fang 1,784 meters into the Namib sky. This 'Matterhorn of Namibia' displays fantastic rock formations sculpted by wind and time. Walk among rounded boulders, discover San rock paintings in rock shelters.

activities.text: Route to Spitzkoppe via Henties Bay. The C34 follows the coast north before turning inland on the D1918. The massive granite peaks appear on the horizon, increasingly imposing. Arrival at community campsite for pitch selection among boulders.
Afternoon exploration. Follow marked trails to the rock arch, search for San paintings in shelters, climb onto boulders for views. Each rock formation tells millions of years of geology.

Starry night at Spitzkoppe. This site is renowned for having one of the purest skies in the world. Once night falls and city lights are hundreds of kilometers away, the Milky Way spreads across the sky in all its glory. Photographers capture star trails above granite peaks.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure

visits.text: The Welwitschia plains host these prehistoric plants that can live over 2,000 years. The 'Moon Landscape' route crosses surreal valleys carved by erosion. Book the excursion with a guide – permit required.

Cape Cross Seal Reserve shelters a colony of 80,000-100,000 Cape fur seals. The spectacle is extraordinary: thousands of animals barking, swimming, sprawling on rocks. The smell is powerful. Bring binoculars to observe pups and fishing adults.

The stone cross erected by Portuguese navigator Diego Cão in 1486 stands on the site. This padrão marks the farthest point south reached by Europeans at that time. A replica replaces the original, preserved in a museum.
You leave Sesriem heading northwest towards the coast. The drive is long (about 5 hours) but varied in landscapes.
You cross mountain passes, lunar plains and finally reach the Atlantic Ocean at Walvis Bay.
Swakopmund, a seaside resort town, displays surprising German colonial architecture for this corner of Africa.
The town offers a laid-back atmosphere, restaurants, shops and sandy beaches along the cold ocean.

activities.text: Long crossing to the Atlantic coast. The C14 and C28 cross the heart of Namib-Naukluft Park. Dry riverbeds, lunar plains, then gradual descent towards the ocean. Refuel at Solitaire, last station before the coast.

Arrival in Swakopmund. This seaside town with Germanic architecture surprises: half-timbered houses, bakeries, beer gardens facing the Atlantic. Camp setup then stroll on the jetty. Mist rolls in, temperature drops. After desert heat, oceanic freshness feels like a gift.
Morning excursion to Cape Cross. The tar road north follows the Skeleton Coast. Seal colony visit, then possible stop at saltpans on the return. Count half a day round trip from Swakopmund.
Free afternoon in Swakopmund. Options: sandboarding on coastal dunes, kayaking with seals at Walvis Bay, or simply stroll the promenade and enjoy a German pastry. Supermarket shopping for next leg.
Detour via Walvis Bay to observe the pink flamingos colony at the lagoon.
Stroll through Swakopmund's German colonial quarter and its colorful buildings.
Try activities: sandboarding on dunes, quad biking, scenic flight over the desert, or boat trip to see seals.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure
Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: Twyfelfontein UNESCO site 2500 rock engravings petroglyphs 6000 years.
San bushmen rock art animal representations giraffes elephants rhinoceros.
Organ Pipes basaltic column formations 120 million years.
Burnt Mountain burnt mountain red purple colors oxidation.

Twyfelfontein holds 2,500 rock engravings and paintings created by San hunter-gatherers 6,000 years ago. This UNESCO site displays lions, elephants, rhinos, giraffes engraved on sandstone. Guided visit mandatory to protect this exceptional heritage.
The Organ Pipes are spectacular vertical basalt columns formed by volcanic cooling 120 million years ago. These geometric formations stretch over 100 meters, creating a natural pipe organ.

The Burnt Mountain displays stunning colors: ochre, purple, rust, black. Volcanic rocks oxidized over time create this chromatic palette. Morning light intensifies the hues. Short stop but spectacular visual impact.
You reach the Twyfelfontein region, a UNESCO World Heritage site for its exceptional concentration of prehistoric rock engravings.
More than 2,500 petroglyphs and paintings, dating from 6,000 years ago, depict wildlife and mysterious geometric patterns.
The surrounding landscape is spectacular, with red rocks, desert valleys and unique rock formations like Organ Pipes and Burnt Mountain.

activities.text: Guided visit Twyfelfontein rock engravings prehistoric art spiritual meanings.
Hike Organ Pipes geological formations spectacular basaltic columns.
Exploration Burnt Mountain mineral colors bright sunset.
Desert elephant observation unique adaptation Damaraland arid survival.
Sundowner rocks panoramas desert mountains.
Springbok potjie stewed game meat.
Beer Tafel Lager wine Pinotage.

Route through Damaraland. The C39 and D2612 cross wild landscapes: red plains, scattered mountains, dry riverbeds where desert elephants sometimes wander. Long gravel section, allow time for landscapes and potential wildlife.
Afternoon at the campsite. Choose from several options around Twyfelfontein. Some offer pools, others focus on wilderness. Relax before tomorrow's guided visit that must be booked at reception.
Guided tour of Twyfelfontein rock engravings (mandatory guided visit).
Visit the Organ Pipes, natural basalt columns formed 120 million years ago.
Explore Burnt Mountain, colorful rock formation with shades of red, purple and brown.
Optional visit to Living Museum of the Damara, cultural experience with local community.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia's Northern Wilderness: Damaraland to Kaokoland Safari Adventure
Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure
Namibia to Okavango Delta 4x4 Safari — Complete 20-Day Self-Drive Adventure

visits.text: The Waterberg Plateau rises like a fortress of red sandstone 200 meters above surrounding plains. This massif shelters Namibia's last refuges for black rhinos and Cape vultures. The microclimate created by cliff springs feeds lush vegetation contrasting with dry surroundings.

activities.text: Last dawn safari at Etosha. Make the most of final hours in the park. One last loop around Namutoni waterholes before reluctantly taking the road to Von Lindequist Gate. Exit the park around mid-morning.

Route to Waterberg. Exit Etosha via Von Lindequist Gate, then the B1 south passes through Otjiwarongo. Stop for fuel and lunch. The C22 climbs towards Waterberg, landscape changing from flat bush to mountainous terrain.

Afternoon at Waterberg camp. Installation at the foot of cliffs at park camp. Short guided walk to discover local vegetation and history of the 1904 Herero-German battle. Or simply rest by the pool contemplating red cliffs.

days_plan.itin_title: Namibia 4x4 Self-Drive Safari: 15-Day Rooftop Tent Adventure

visits.text: The Christuskirche stands with its neo-Gothic silhouette at the heart of Windhoek since 1910. This Lutheran church with golden stones remains the most photographed landmark in the Namibian capital.
The Independence Memorial Museum dominates the city with its modern architecture. Climb to the top for a free panoramic view over Windhoek and the surrounding hills.
Stroll through the aisles of the Namibia Craft Centre housed in the old breweries. Forty artisans display wood carvings, copper jewelry, and traditional textiles.
Okahandja Market is famous for its woodcarving artisans. Sculptures, masks, bowls, animals – Namibian craftsmanship on display. Prices are negotiable. This is the ideal place for final souvenirs.
Hosea Kutako Airport bears the name of the Herero national hero who fought for independence. This modern but human-scale terminal offers some duty-free shops and cafes to wait before boarding.
You land at Windhoek International Airport midday. After formalities, you pick up your rental vehicle.
The rental team explains the essential points related to driving in Namibia, then you head towards the city center.
In about forty minutes, you reach the center of Windhoek. You settle in comfortably and have the rest of the afternoon at your own pace.
Windhoek, Namibia's capital, surprises at first sight with its feeling of a small provincial town. Nothing like what you'd imagine an African capital to be.
The capital is undoubtedly the best place to eat at restaurants in Namibia. Menus reflect German, French, Indian, Chinese, Argentine and Portuguese influences.

activities.text: 4x4 vehicle rental with rooftop tent. Windhoek agencies offer fully equipped double-cab vehicles. Allow 2 hours for the complete briefing: tent assembly, compressor use, tire pressure adjustment, procedure in case of getting stuck. Check tire condition, hi-lift jack, jerry cans, and spare wheel.

Shopping provisions. Downtown supermarkets allow you to stock up for several days. Buy enough to be self-sufficient: water (5L per person per day), canned goods, firewood, cooler. Shopping centers offer the widest selection.

Camping near airport if late arrival. The reserve 25 km away offers first contact with Namibian wildlife: oryx, giraffes, zebras. Shaded sites with facilities, ideal for a recovery night after the flight.

Optional morning hike at Waterberg. The Dassie-Fountain-Porcupine loop (10.5 km) explores ravines and springs before climbing to a breathtaking viewpoint. Leave early to avoid heat. Shorter alternative: Aloe Circle + Fig Tree Walk (3.9 km).
Route to Windhoek via the B1 tar road. These 280 km fly by effortlessly after two weeks of gravel roads. Last fuel stop in Otjiwarongo or Okahandja.
Final souvenir shopping in Windhoek. The Namibia Craft Centre offers authentic crafts: wood carvings, copper jewelry, traditional textiles.
Vehicle return. Plan for full tank and 1h for inspection. Photograph the vehicle before return to avoid disputes.
Camping or accommodation near airport. If your flight leaves early the next day, lodges near Hosea Kutako airport avoid last-morning stress.
Transfer to airport. Allow 2h30 before your flight for formalities. International flights generally transit through Johannesburg, Addis Ababa, or Frankfurt depending on your destination.

Final glance at Namibia. In the plane rising above the plateau, landscapes scroll by one last time: the green of Waterberg, Etosha bush, red dunes of the Namib in the distance. Namibia has transformed you – you will return.
Pick up your camping-equipped 4x4 from one of Windhoek's rental companies. Allow 2 hours for the complete briefing and vehicle inspection.
Stock up on groceries at Windhoek supermarkets: water (minimum 5L/person/day), canned goods, firewood, cooler.
Depending on your mood, you can stay put, walk around the immediate surroundings, or book a table at one of the neighborhood restaurants.
If arriving late, several campsites welcome travelers near Windhoek.
